multi networking for moat for the most part Cooper applications they
don't really care about networking beyond the fact that they have an IP address that they might be the backend
for a service everything works great you're in the cloud and you can just forget about the network and build your application the
way that you want to build it and have it all run perfectly however there are
some cases and this is you know the things that we found out and tried to identify over the last year in the
plumbing working group where that's not always the case that doesn't always work
out for everybody a lot of these workloads are have special requirements
on the network and it may end up being that you need to think a little bit more about the networking and your pod needs
to think a little bit more about the networking as you try to accommodate some of these requirements in kubernetes
so what do we actually mean by any of these workloads these are some of the
things we identified for example if you have specific performance and bandwidth requirements for your application
oftentimes that can't be accommodated by a lot of the cloud providers so a lot of
companies are looking at on-premise deployments for kubernetes to kind of
provide their own hardware that might have or be able to provide for these special requirements alongside that
they're also latency and QoS requirements sometimes you don't initially want all
of the control plane traffic for the entire cluster where the nodes are talking to the Masters and the API
servers and all that kind of back-and-forth communication that actually runs and orchestrates your cluster you don't necessarily want that
to impact your data traffic and in the default case most clusters are organized
so that all of the pod data and control traffic for the cluster go over the same network link and if you want to make
sure that your application has specific requirements of latency QoS guaranteed bandwidth you may not be able to use the
same networks that the control traffic goes out over also some businesses have requirements around segregated networks
for security or regulatory or whatever means that mean that some traffic has to
go over one network some traffic has to go over another oftentimes that means physically separated networks in one of
the last areas that we identified is for legacy network resources where you might have something like a database
or some other application outside your cluster that you cannot actually move into the cluster or that you cannot read
number for whatever reason and so you want your pods to be able to talk directly to that resource this doesn't
mean that you can't do some of these things in a more cloud native way or have proxies that bridge these kinds of
resources back to your cluster but oftentimes that's a little bit more complicated than a lot of people want to
deal with so network plumbing working Europe what is this working group well

questions around how we take these workloads and make them slightly more cloud natives let the more kubernetes
aware and containerized how we address some of those needs in kubernetes we'd

something that we discovered early on as we went to create the specification
is that really when you have a pod come up you expect that it can communicate
like your everyday average run-of-the-mill pod it should have connectivity to other pods so you'll

then we'll refer to the other network attachments the other interfaces that
you have available in the pod sometimes we'll refer to those as sidecar networks granted that's a little bit of an

to tell the kubernetes api to store some data for us so we have a net definition
